words.definition: to stimulate or shock into action
sentences: The speech galvanized the crowd into action.
Her words galvanized support for the cause.

words.definition: excessively talkative, especially about trivial matters
sentences: The garrulous neighbor talked for hours about nothing.
He became more garrulous after drinking coffee.

words.definition: lacking social grace or awareness; awkward
sentences: His gauche behavior embarrassed everyone at dinner.
She made a gauche comment about the host's weight.

words.definition: friendly and cheerful in manner
sentences: The genial host made everyone feel welcome.
His genial smile put the nervous guests at ease.

words.definition: relevant and appropriate to the matter at hand
sentences: Her comments were not germane to the discussion.
Please keep your questions germane to the topic.

words.definition: an excessive supply or amount
sentences: There was a glut of oil on the market.
The glut of applicants made hiring difficult.

words.definition: given or done without good reason; unnecessary
sentences: The movie contained gratuitous violence.
His gratuitous insults offended everyone.

words.definition: fond of company; sociable
sentences: She was gregarious and loved attending parties.
The gregarious puppy greeted every visitor warmly.

words.definition: sly or cunning intelligence
sentences: He used guile to trick his opponents.
She lacked the guile necessary for politics.

words.definition: easily persuaded to believe something
sentences: The gullible tourist fell for the scam.
Don't be so gullible; that story is obviously false.

words.definition: lacking originality; overused
sentences: The writer relied on hackneyed phrases.
His hackneyed jokes failed to amuse the audience.

words.definition: to hinder or impede movement or progress
sentences: Heavy rain hampered rescue efforts.
Poor equipment hampered the team's performance.

words.definition: lacking any obvious order or planning
sentences: The books were arranged in a haphazard manner.
His haphazard approach led to many mistakes.

words.definition: a lengthy and aggressive speech
sentences: The manager delivered a harangue about tardiness.
We endured his harangue for over an hour.

words.definition: a person or thing that announces the approach of something
sentences: The robin is a harbinger of spring.
His resignation was a harbinger of changes to come.

words.definition: able to endure difficult conditions; robust
sentences: Only hardy plants survive in the desert.
The hardy explorers braved the Arctic cold.

words.definition: arrogantly superior and disdainful
sentences: Her haughty manner alienated potential friends.
The haughty waiter looked down on the customers.

words.definition: a person who pursues pleasure above all else
sentences: The hedonist spent his fortune on luxury goods.
She dismissed him as a shallow hedonist.

words.definition: belief contrary to accepted doctrine
sentences: His ideas were considered heresy by the church.
Questioning the company policy was treated as heresy.

words.definition: diverse in character or content
sentences: The city has a heterogeneous population.
The class was heterogeneous in age and background.

words.definition: a pause or gap in continuity
sentences: The band took a hiatus after their world tour.
There was a brief hiatus in the negotiations.

words.definition: a system of ranking people or things
sentences: The company has a strict hierarchy.
She quickly rose through the corporate hierarchy.

words.definition: understanding of a situation after it has happened
sentences: In hindsight, the decision was clearly wrong.
Hindsight revealed many missed opportunities.

words.definition: of the same kind; uniform throughout
sentences: The neighborhood was culturally homogeneous.
The mixture should be smooth and homogeneous.

words.definition: exaggerated statements not meant to be taken literally
sentences: Saying he's the best ever is pure hyperbole.
Her story was filled with hyperbole.

words.definition: pretending to have beliefs one does not actually hold
sentences: It was hypocritical of him to criticize others.
Her hypocritical stance angered her supporters.

words.definition: a proposed explanation for a phenomenon
sentences: The scientist tested her hypothesis in the lab.
His hypothesis proved to be correct.

words.definition: exaggerated or uncontrollable emotion
sentences: Mass hysteria swept through the crowd.
The news caused hysteria among investors.

words.definition: a person who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions
sentences: The artist was an iconoclast who challenged traditions.
As an iconoclast, she questioned everything.

words.definition: a distinctive or peculiar characteristic
sentences: Her habit of humming was an endearing idiosyncrasy.
Each writer has unique idiosyncrasies.

words.definition: not honorable in character or purpose
sentences: His ignoble behavior shocked his family.
The politician's ignoble motives were exposed.

words.definition: forbidden by law, rules, or custom
sentences: The police uncovered an illicit drug operation.
Their illicit affair destroyed two marriages.

words.definition: about to happen very soon
sentences: The storm's arrival was imminent.
They sensed that danger was imminent.

words.definition: unchanging over time; permanent
sentences: The laws of physics are immutable.
Her immutable principles guided every decision.

words.definition: treating all rivals or disputants equally; fair
sentences: A judge must remain impartial.
She gave an impartial assessment of the situation.

words.definition: a situation in which no progress is possible
sentences: The negotiations reached an impasse.
They found a way to break the impasse.

words.definition: without flaw or error; perfect
sentences: Her impeccable manners impressed everyone.
The chef has an impeccable reputation.

words.definition: to delay or prevent by obstructing
sentences: Heavy traffic impeded our progress.
Nothing could impede her determination.

words.definition: about to happen; imminent
sentences: She sensed the impending crisis.
The impending deadline caused stress.

words.definition: of vital importance; crucial
sentences: It is imperative that we act now.
Speed was imperative in the rescue mission.

words.definition: arrogant and domineering
sentences: His imperious tone offended his colleagues.
She issued imperious commands to her staff.

words.definition: rude and disrespectful
sentences: The student asked an impertinent question.
His impertinent remarks were not appreciated.

words.definition: acting quickly without thought or care
sentences: His impetuous decision caused problems.
She made an impetuous purchase she later regretted.

words.definition: not allowing something to pass through; unaffected
sentences: The material is impervious to water.
She seemed impervious to criticism.

words.definition: unable to be appeased or pacified
sentences: He faced an implacable enemy.
Her implacable anger lasted for years.

words.definition: not seeming reasonable or probable
sentences: His excuse was completely implausible.
The plot of the movie was implausible.

words.definition: implied though not directly expressed
sentences: There was an implicit threat in his words.
Her implicit trust in him was touching.

words.definition: made poor; lacking resources
sentences: The war left the country impoverished.
Many impoverished families need assistance.

words.definition: not having or showing foresight; wasteful
sentences: His improvident spending led to bankruptcy.
They were improvident with their resources.

words.definition: not showing proper respect; impertinent
sentences: The impudent child talked back to his teacher.
Her impudent behavior shocked the guests.

words.definition: to attribute something to someone
sentences: They imputed the crime to the wrong person.
Don't impute motives that don't exist.

words.definition: not resulting from deliberate planning; accidental
sentences: It was an inadvertent error.
Her inadvertent comment hurt his feelings.

words.definition: silly and pointless
sentences: The show was full of inane humor.
His inane questions wasted everyone's time.

words.definition: designed to cause fires; inflammatory
sentences: The incendiary device caused the explosion.
His incendiary speech provoked riots.

words.definition: continuing without pause or interruption
sentences: The incessant noise kept us awake.
She complained about his incessant talking.

words.definition: intelligently analytical and clear-thinking
sentences: Her incisive comments cut to the heart of the matter.
The journalist asked incisive questions.

words.definition: to encourage or stir up violent or unlawful behavior
sentences: The speaker tried to incite the crowd.
His words incited a rebellion.

words.definition: not in harmony or keeping with the surroundings
sentences: The modern building looked incongruous in the old town.
His casual attire was incongruous at the formal event.

words.definition: not important or significant
sentences: The error was inconsequential.
They argued over inconsequential matters.

words.definition: not able to be denied or disputed
sentences: The evidence was incontrovertible.
She presented incontrovertible facts.

words.definition: not able to be corrected or reformed
sentences: He was an incorrigible troublemaker.
Her incorrigible optimism never faded.

words.definition: unwilling or unable to believe something
sentences: She gave him an incredulous look.
The audience was incredulous at the news.

words.definition: to instill an idea through persistent instruction
sentences: Parents try to inculcate good values in their children.
The school inculcates a love of learning.

words.definition: necessary for someone as a duty; currently holding office
sentences: It is incumbent upon us to help.
The incumbent president sought reelection.

words.definition: having no particular interest or concern
sentences: He seemed indifferent to her suffering.
The audience was indifferent to the performance.

words.definition: originating naturally in a particular place
sentences: The plant is indigenous to South America.
We studied the indigenous peoples of the region.

words.definition: poor; needy
sentences: The charity helps indigent families.
Indigent patients receive free care.

words.definition: feeling or showing anger at perceived unfair treatment
sentences: She was indignant about the false accusations.
His indignant response surprised everyone.

words.definition: wanting to avoid activity or exertion; lazy
sentences: The indolent student rarely did homework.
He spent an indolent summer by the pool.

words.definition: impossible to subdue or defeat
sentences: Her indomitable spirit inspired others.
The team showed indomitable courage.

words.definition: to succeed in persuading someone to do something
sentences: Nothing could induce him to change his mind.
The medicine induced sleep.

words.definition: too great or extreme to be expressed in words
sentences: She felt an ineffable sense of joy.
The beauty of the sunset was ineffable.

words.definition: having or showing no skill; clumsy
sentences: His inept handling of the situation made things worse.
The inept waiter spilled water everywhere.

words.definition: lacking the ability or strength to move
sentences: The patient lay inert on the bed.
Helium is an inert gas.

words.definition: impossible to stop or prevent
sentences: The inexorable march of time continues.
His inexorable pursuit of justice never wavered.

words.definition: well known for some bad quality or deed
sentences: The infamous criminal was finally captured.
The town is infamous for its harsh winters.

words.definition: the state of being well known for bad qualities
sentences: The scandal brought him infamy.
The date will live in infamy.

words.definition: clever, original, and inventive
sentences: She devised an ingenious solution.
The ingenious design won many awards.

words.definition: innocent and unsuspecting; artless
sentences: Her ingenuous nature made her easy to deceive.
He asked the question with ingenuous curiosity.

words.definition: existing as a permanent, essential quality
sentences: There are inherent risks in the plan.
Creativity is inherent in all children.

words.definition: to hinder or restrain an action or process
sentences: Fear can inhibit creativity.
The drug inhibits the growth of cancer cells.

words.definition: tending to obstruct or harm; hostile
sentences: The policy was inimical to their interests.
Such behavior is inimical to team spirit.

words.definition: not harmful or offensive
sentences: It seemed like an innocuous remark.
The substance is completely innocuous.

words.definition: to introduce new methods, ideas, or products
sentences: The company continues to innovate.
We must innovate to stay competitive.

words.definition: an indirect or subtle suggestion, usually negative
sentences: The article was full of innuendo.
She ignored his innuendo about her past.

words.definition: impossible to satisfy
sentences: He had an insatiable appetite for knowledge.
Her insatiable curiosity drove her research.

words.definition: proceeding in a subtle way with harmful effects
sentences: The disease has an insidious onset.
Rumors can have an insidious effect.

words.definition: to suggest something bad in an indirect way
sentences: She insinuated that he was lying.
He insinuated himself into her confidence.

words.definition: lacking flavor or interest; dull
sentences: The soup was insipid and bland.
His insipid speech bored the audience.

words.definition: showing a rude and arrogant lack of respect
sentences: The insolent student was sent to the principal.
His insolent reply shocked his parents.

words.definition: to bring about or initiate an action
sentences: He was accused of instigating the riot.
She instigated changes in the organization.

words.definition: ignorant of or uninterested in cultures beyond one's own
sentences: The community had an insular mentality.
His insular views limited his understanding.

words.definition: a rebel or revolutionary
sentences: The insurgents attacked the military base.
Government forces captured the insurgent leader.

words.definition: unable to be touched or grasped; not having physical presence
sentences: Happiness is an intangible quality.
The company's intangible assets include its reputation.

words.definition: essential or fundamental to completeness
sentences: She is an integral part of the team.
Music is integral to their culture.

words.definition: the quality of being honest and having strong moral principles
sentences: His integrity was never questioned.
She acted with complete integrity.

words.definition: occurring at irregular intervals; not continuous
sentences: The rain was intermittent throughout the day.
She received intermittent signals on her phone.

words.definition: fearless and adventurous
sentences: The intrepid explorer ventured into unknown territory.
Only the intrepid dared to climb the mountain.

words.definition: very complicated or detailed
sentences: The watch has an intricate mechanism.
She designed an intricate pattern.

words.definition: belonging naturally; essential
sentences: Kindness has intrinsic value.
The intrinsic beauty of nature inspired the artist.

words.definition: characterized by examination of one's own thoughts
sentences: She became more introspective as she aged.
The introspective poet wrote about inner struggles.

words.definition: to overwhelm with things to be dealt with
sentences: The office was inundated with complaints.
Heavy rains inundated the town.

words.definition: to make something legally or officially unacceptable
sentences: The court invalidated the law.
New evidence could invalidate the theory.

words.definition: insulting or abusive language
sentences: He launched into a stream of invective.
The debate descended into invective.

words.definition: having a long-standing habit that is unlikely to change
sentences: He was an inveterate gambler.
Her inveterate optimism never faded.

words.definition: too powerful to be defeated or overcome
sentences: The team seemed invincible that season.
No army is truly invincible.

words.definition: easily angered; irritable
sentences: The irascible old man yelled at the children.
His irascible temper made him difficult to work with.

words.definition: showing a lack of respect for things normally treated seriously
sentences: His irreverent humor shocked some people.
The irreverent comedian mocked politicians.

words.definition: traveling from place to place
sentences: The itinerant musician played in different cities.
Itinerant workers followed the harvest.

words.definition: tired and lacking enthusiasm after too much exposure
sentences: The jaded critic had seen it all before.
Years of rejection left her jaded.

words.definition: special words used by a particular profession or group
sentences: The document was full of legal jargon.
Please avoid technical jargon in your presentation.

words.definition: affected by bitterness or resentment
sentences: He had a jaundiced view of politics.
Her jaundiced perspective came from past failures.

words.definition: to put someone or something into a situation of risk
sentences: His actions could jeopardize the mission.
Don't jeopardize your health by smoking.

words.definition: cheerful and friendly
sentences: The jovial host greeted everyone warmly.
His jovial personality made him popular.

words.definition: feeling or expressing great happiness and triumph
sentences: The team was jubilant after winning.
Jubilant crowds filled the streets.

words.definition: having or showing good judgment
sentences: She made a judicious decision.
Judicious use of resources is essential.

words.definition: to place close together for contrasting effect
sentences: The artist juxtaposed light and dark colors.
The film juxtaposes wealth and poverty.

words.definition: to light a fire; to arouse an emotion
sentences: He kindled a fire in the fireplace.
The speech kindled hope in the audience.

words.definition: relating to or resulting from motion
sentences: The sculpture had a kinetic quality.
Kinetic energy increases with speed.

words.definition: a skill or talent for doing something easily
sentences: She has a knack for languages.
He had a knack for making people laugh.

words.definition: requiring considerable effort and time
sentences: The laborious task took all day.
Writing the report was a laborious process.

words.definition: using very few words
sentences: His laconic reply gave nothing away.
The laconic message simply said goodbye.

words.definition: to publicly criticize using ridicule or sarcasm
sentences: The show lampooned political figures.
Satirists love to lampoon celebrities.

words.definition: lacking energy or vitality; slow and relaxed
sentences: The heat made everyone languid.
She stretched in a languid manner.

words.definition: theft of personal property
sentences: He was charged with grand larceny.
Petty larceny carries lighter penalties.

words.definition: generosity in giving money or gifts
sentences: The charity benefited from his largess.
The company distributed its largess to employees.

words.definition: existing but not yet developed or manifest
sentences: She discovered her latent talent for art.
The disease remained latent for years.

words.definition: deserving praise and commendation
sentences: Her efforts were truly laudable.
The organization has a laudable mission.

words.definition: sumptuously rich or elaborate; generous
sentences: They hosted a lavish party.
He was lavish with his compliments.

words.definition: not sufficiently strict or careful
sentences: Security at the building was lax.
Lax enforcement led to more violations.

words.definition: affected by a lack of energy or enthusiasm
sentences: The hot weather made him lethargic.
The lethargic economy showed little growth.

words.definition: humor or lack of seriousness, especially during a serious occasion
sentences: His levity was inappropriate at the funeral.
A moment of levity lightened the mood.

words.definition: thin, supple, and graceful
sentences: The lithe dancer moved effortlessly.
Cats are known for their lithe bodies.

words.definition: of imposing height; elevated in character
sentences: She had lofty ambitions.
The lofty peaks rose above the clouds.

words.definition: tending to talk a great deal
sentences: The loquacious guest dominated the conversation.
He became more loquacious after a few drinks.

words.definition: expressed clearly; easy to understand
sentences: Her explanation was lucid and concise.
He had a lucid moment before falling asleep.

words.definition: so foolish or unreasonable as to be amusing
sentences: The accusation was ludicrous.
It would be ludicrous to believe him.

words.definition: full of or shedding light; bright
sentences: The luminous moon lit the path.
Her luminous smile brightened the room.

words.definition: very generous or forgiving
sentences: She was magnanimous in victory.
His magnanimous gesture surprised everyone.

words.definition: a disease or ailment
sentences: The doctor diagnosed a rare malady.
Poverty is a social malady.

words.definition: a curse
sentences: The witch uttered a malediction.
He believed he was under a malediction.

words.definition: having or showing a wish to do evil to others
sentences: The malevolent villain plotted revenge.
His malevolent stare frightened the children.

words.definition: the intention to do evil or cause harm
sentences: There was no malice in her words.
He acted without malice.

words.definition: easily influenced or shaped
sentences: Young minds are malleable.
Gold is a malleable metal.

words.definition: clear and obvious to the eye or mind
sentences: His joy was manifest to everyone.
The manifest errors needed correction.

words.definition: an independent-minded person who does not conform
sentences: She was a maverick in the industry.
The political maverick challenged party leaders.

words.definition: to follow a winding course; to wander aimlessly
sentences: The river meanders through the valley.
They meandered through the old streets.

words.definition: to intervene between disputing parties to bring about agreement
sentences: She agreed to mediate the dispute.
The diplomat mediated peace talks.

words.definition: a feeling of pensive sadness
sentences: A sense of melancholy filled the room.
The song evoked feelings of melancholy.

words.definition: exaggerated and emotional in behavior or expression
sentences: Her melodramatic reaction annoyed everyone.
The movie was too melodramatic for my taste.

words.definition: not requiring much skill and lacking prestige
sentences: He refused to do menial tasks.
The menial work paid very little.

words.definition: subject to sudden changes of mood or mind
sentences: His mercurial temperament made him unpredictable.
The mercurial artist changed styles often.

words.definition: showing great attention to detail
sentences: She kept meticulous records.
The meticulous craftsman produced perfect work.

words.definition: aggressively active in support of a cause
sentences: The militant protesters blocked the road.
He took a militant stance on the issue.

words.definition: a person who dislikes humankind
sentences: The misanthrope preferred solitude.
Years of disappointment turned him into a misanthrope.

words.definition: to make less severe or serious
sentences: The apology helped mitigate her anger.
Measures were taken to mitigate the damage.

words.definition: unassuming in the estimation of one's abilities
sentences: Despite her success, she remained modest.
He made a modest contribution to the project.

words.definition: to appease the anger or anxiety of someone
sentences: The manager tried to mollify the upset customer.
His apology did little to mollify her.

words.definition: of great importance or significance
sentences: It was a momentous occasion.
The momentous decision changed history.

words.definition: dull and lacking in variety
sentences: The monotonous work bored him.
His monotonous voice put people to sleep.

words.definition: characterized by an unhealthy interest in disturbing subjects
sentences: He had a morbid fascination with death.
Her morbid curiosity led her to the crime scene.

words.definition: sullen and ill-tempered
sentences: He became morose after losing his job.
The morose teenager sat alone in her room.

words.definition: lacking interest or excitement; dull
sentences: She was tired of mundane daily tasks.
The mundane routine bored him.

words.definition: very generous
sentences: The munificent donor gave millions.
His munificent gift funded the new library.

words.definition: a countless or extremely great number
sentences: There are myriad reasons to study.
The sky displayed a myriad of stars.

words.definition: to gather or collect something
sentences: The film garnered critical acclaim.
She garnered support for her proposal.

words.definition: the origin or mode of formation of something
sentences: The book explores the genesis of the universe.
The genesis of the idea came from a dream.

words.definition: polite and refined in manner
sentences: She came from a genteel family.
The genteel atmosphere of the club was welcoming.

words.definition: to use gestures to express or emphasize
sentences: He gesticulated wildly while telling the story.
The speaker gesticulated to make her point.

words.definition: to collect information bit by bit
sentences: She gleaned useful facts from the report.
We gleaned what we could from the old records.

words.definition: fluent but insincere and shallow
sentences: His glib answer did not convince anyone.
Politicians are often accused of being glib.

words.definition: impressive but exaggerated or pretentious
sentences: He had grandiose plans for the company.
The grandiose palace impressed visitors.

words.definition: extreme importance or seriousness
sentences: The gravity of the situation was clear.
She spoke with gravity about the crisis.

words.definition: very severe or serious
sentences: He suffered grievous injuries in the accident.
The grievous mistake cost them the game.

words.definition: given or allowed only reluctantly
sentences: He gave a grudging apology.
She received grudging admiration from critics.

words.definition: to severely restrict the progress of
sentences: Budget cuts hamstrung the project.
The injury hamstrung his athletic career.

words.definition: unfortunate and deserving pity
sentences: The hapless victim lost everything.
The hapless traveler missed his flight.

words.definition: extremely distressing or disturbing
sentences: The survivors told harrowing stories.
It was a harrowing experience for everyone.

words.definition: to pay attention to; to take notice of
sentences: You should heed her advice.
They failed to heed the warning signs.

words.definition: utterly wicked or evil
sentences: The heinous crime shocked the nation.
He was guilty of heinous acts.

words.definition: to be a sign that something is about to happen
sentences: The discovery heralded a new era.
Dark clouds heralded the approaching storm.

words.definition: completely sealed; airtight
sentences: The container has a hermetic seal.
The hermetic society kept outsiders away.

words.definition: to create difficulties for someone or something
sentences: Bad weather hindered the search.
Lack of funds hindered progress.

words.definition: characterized by treating the whole person or system
sentences: She takes a holistic approach to health.
Holistic medicine considers mind and body.

words.definition: excessive pride or self-confidence
sentences: His hubris led to his downfall.
The CEO's hubris alienated employees.

words.definition: a modest view of one's own importance
sentences: She accepted the award with humility.
Humility is an admirable quality.

words.definition: to use resources economically and carefully
sentences: They learned to husband their supplies.
She husbanded her strength for the final push.

words.definition: criticizing or attacking cherished beliefs
sentences: His iconoclastic views angered traditionalists.
The iconoclastic artist challenged conventions.

words.definition: extremely happy, peaceful, or picturesque
sentences: They spent an idyllic summer by the lake.
The village had an idyllic charm.

words.definition: public shame or disgrace
sentences: He suffered the ignominy of defeat.
The scandal brought ignominy to the family.

words.definition: to light up; to make clear
sentences: The candles illuminated the room.
Her explanation illuminated the complex topic.

words.definition: based on illusion; not real
sentences: The promise of quick wealth proved illusory.
Their sense of security was illusory.

words.definition: to inspire or permeate with a quality or feeling
sentences: The teacher imbued students with curiosity.
The ceremony was imbued with tradition.

words.definition: to involve deeply in a particular activity
sentences: She immersed herself in her studies.
The artist was immersed in his work.

words.definition: not feeling or showing emotion
sentences: His face remained impassive during the trial.
She listened with an impassive expression.

words.definition: the quality of being without flaw or error
sentences: Her impeccability was admired by all.
The impeccability of his work set high standards.

words.definition: to put at risk of harm or destruction
sentences: Pollution imperils marine life.
His reckless behavior imperiled the mission.

words.definition: the force or energy with which something moves
sentences: The scandal provided the impetus for reform.
New funding gave impetus to the project.

words.definition: to beg someone earnestly to do something
sentences: She implored him to stay.
They implored the government for help.

words.definition: unable to be captured or broken into
sentences: The fortress was considered impregnable.
Her argument seemed impregnable.

words.definition: exemption from punishment or harmful consequences
sentences: He acted with impunity.
They broke the rules with impunity.

words.definition: just begun and not fully formed
sentences: The plan was still inchoate.
She had only an inchoate understanding of the topic.

words.definition: beginning to happen or develop
sentences: We detected incipient signs of rebellion.
The incipient disease was caught early.

words.definition: owing gratitude for a service or favor
sentences: I am indebted to you for your help.
She felt indebted to her mentors.

words.definition: making marks that cannot be erased; unforgettable
sentences: The experience left an indelible impression.
Use indelible ink for official documents.

words.definition: a formal accusation of a serious crime
sentences: The grand jury issued an indictment.
The report was an indictment of the system.

words.definition: done at random or without careful judgment
sentences: The bombing caused indiscriminate destruction.
His indiscriminate praise meant little.

words.definition: absolutely necessary
sentences: Water is indispensable to life.
She became indispensable to the team.

words.definition: impossible to defeat or discourage
sentences: Her indomitable will kept her going.
The team showed indomitable spirit.

words.definition: having or indicating a readiness to be generous
sentences: The indulgent grandmother spoiled her grandchildren.
He was too indulgent with his employees.

words.definition: to deduce from evidence and reasoning
sentences: We can infer her intentions from her actions.
The detective inferred the truth.

words.definition: extremely small
sentences: The risk was infinitesimal.
There was only an infinitesimal chance of success.

words.definition: intended to arouse strong feelings
sentences: His inflammatory remarks caused an uproar.
The article was considered inflammatory.

words.definition: to fill with a quality or element
sentences: She infused the team with enthusiasm.
The chef infused the oil with herbs.

words.definition: a slight knowledge or suspicion
sentences: I had no inkling of what was to come.
She gave me an inkling of the surprise.

words.definition: impossible to understand or interpret
sentences: His inscrutable expression gave nothing away.
The ancient text remained inscrutable.

words.definition: ignorant of or uninterested in outside views
sentences: The insular community resisted change.
His insular mindset limited his perspective.

words.definition: a person who becomes involved without invitation
sentences: The locals viewed the newcomer as an interloper.
She felt like an interloper at the family gathering.

words.definition: endless or seeming to have no end
sentences: The meeting seemed interminable.
We endured interminable delays.

words.definition: hard to control or deal with
sentences: The problem proved intractable.
The intractable child refused to listen.

words.definition: unwilling or refusing to change one's views
sentences: The intransigent negotiators could not agree.
Her intransigent attitude blocked progress.

words.definition: to accustom to something unpleasant
sentences: Soldiers become inured to danger.
Years of hardship inured her to suffering.

words.definition: to call upon as authority or support
sentences: She invoked the Fifth Amendment.
He invoked the name of the law.

words.definition: feeling or showing extreme anger
sentences: The irate customer demanded a refund.
He became irate when kept waiting.

words.definition: irritating or annoying
sentences: The constant noise was irksome.
She found his habits irksome.

words.definition: happening in a way contrary to what is expected
sentences: It was ironic that the fire station burned down.
She made an ironic comment about the delay.

words.definition: showing or feeling hesitancy; uncertain
sentences: The irresolute leader failed to act.
She was irresolute about her career path.

words.definition: fond of or characterized by joking
sentences: His jocular manner put people at ease.
She made a jocular remark about the weather.

words.definition: lacking in vitality, force, or conviction
sentences: The team gave a lackluster performance.
His lackluster speech failed to inspire.

words.definition: to express sorrow or regret about something
sentences: She lamented the loss of her friend.
Critics lament the decline of traditional arts.

words.definition: something handed down from the past
sentences: The library is part of his legacy.
She wanted to leave a lasting legacy.

words.definition: merciful or tolerant
sentences: The judge was lenient with first offenders.
Her lenient parents rarely punished her.

words.definition: sufficient to cause death
sentences: The snake's venom is lethal.
He faced a lethal combination of threats.

words.definition: to stay in a place longer than necessary
sentences: The smell of perfume lingered in the room.
He lingered at the party until midnight.

words.definition: lacking energy or enthusiasm
sentences: The heat made everyone listless.
She felt listless after the illness.

words.definition: taking words in their usual meaning without exaggeration
sentences: His literal interpretation missed the humor.
The literal meaning differs from the metaphorical one.

words.definition: to resolve a dispute in a court of law
sentences: They decided to litigate the matter.
The company prefers to litigate rather than settle.

words.definition: to feel intense dislike or disgust for
sentences: She loathed getting up early.
He loathed dishonesty in any form.

words.definition: of imposing height; noble in nature
sentences: The castle had lofty towers.
She had lofty ideals.

words.definition: producing a great deal of profit
sentences: The business proved to be lucrative.
She turned her hobby into a lucrative career.

words.definition: a temporary interval of quiet or lack of activity
sentences: There was a lull in the conversation.
The lull before the storm was eerie.

words.definition: having a gentle sheen or soft glow
sentences: Her lustrous hair caught the light.
The pearl had a lustrous surface.

words.definition: a scheming or crafty action
sentences: The villain's machinations were exposed.
Corporate machinations led to the scandal.

words.definition: a powerful whirlpool; a turbulent situation
sentences: The ship was caught in a maelstrom.
The political maelstrom consumed the nation.

words.definition: a wealthy and influential person in business
sentences: The oil magnate donated millions to charity.
She became a media magnate.

words.definition: to speak about someone in a spitefully critical manner
sentences: Critics maligned her work unfairly.
He was maligned by his political opponents.

words.definition: an official order or commission to do something
sentences: The law created a mandate for change.
The president had a clear mandate from voters.

words.definition: to impair the quality or appearance of
sentences: Scratches marred the surface of the table.
The scandal marred his reputation.

words.definition: to arrange or assemble in order
sentences: She marshaled her thoughts before speaking.
The general marshaled his troops.

words.definition: a person who suffers for a cause or belief
sentences: He was considered a martyr for the cause.
She portrayed herself as a martyr.

words.definition: to pretend to be someone one is not
sentences: He masqueraded as a doctor.
The email masqueraded as official correspondence.

words.definition: a short statement expressing a general truth
sentences: He lived by the maxim to treat others well.
The old maxim still holds true.

words.definition: lacking in quantity or quality
sentences: The refugees survived on meager rations.
His meager salary barely covered expenses.

words.definition: to interfere in something that is not one's concern
sentences: She didn't want to meddle in their affairs.
Stop meddling in my business.

words.definition: a person or thing that threatens danger or harm
sentences: The storm was a menace to shipping.
He was considered a menace to society.

words.definition: an experienced and trusted adviser
sentences: She found a mentor to guide her career.
The mentor shared valuable insights.

words.definition: primarily concerned with making money
sentences: His mercenary motives were obvious.
The mercenary soldiers fought for pay.

words.definition: to involve in difficulties; a swampy ground
sentences: The project was mired in controversy.
The car got mired in mud.

words.definition: to interpret wrongly
sentences: His words were misconstrued by the media.
Don't misconstrue my silence as agreement.

words.definition: a feeling of doubt or apprehension
sentences: She had misgivings about the plan.
Despite his misgivings, he agreed to help.

words.definition: to tease or laugh at in a scornful manner
sentences: The bullies mocked his accent.
She mocked his attempts to dance.

words.definition: a small quantity of something
sentences: She had a modicum of talent.
A modicum of common sense would help.

words.definition: at the point of death; lacking vitality
sentences: The moribund industry needed reform.
The patient was moribund.

words.definition: incongruously varied in appearance or character
sentences: The motley crew assembled for the mission.
A motley collection of items filled the room.

words.definition: having many facets or aspects
sentences: The issue is multifaceted and complex.
She had a multifaceted career.

words.definition: to be absorbed in thought
sentences: She mused about her future.
He mused on the meaning of life.

words.definition: liable to change
sentences: Fashion is highly mutable.
Human nature is mutable.

words.definition: refraining from speech or temporarily speechless
sentences: She remained mute during the questioning.
The mute witness could not testify.

words.definition: an open rebellion against authority
sentences: The sailors staged a mutiny.
There was talk of mutiny among the crew.
